pageContext.desc: Written from the Oklahoma Territory, the Southwest, and the Dakotas, regarding his commissioned series of portraits of prominent Indian Chiefs.
pageContext.category: Edward E. Ayer Manuscript Collection; Indians of North America; Letters (Correspondence)

pages.transcription:
Sac & Fox
Agency
Okla. T.
Nov. 22. 1900.
My dear Uncle.
There are two
only descendants of
Black hawk living
near here two brothers
one is 48 years old the
other 60 and Black hawk
was their Grandfather
The one 48 is sitting
for me in genuine
Sac & Fox costume
I had the worst time
to get him he was
so awfully superstitious 
finally he consented

to sit his face is all
painted up and he
wears on his head
a thing made from
Wild Turkey whiskers
that have always been
worth a horse each.
He is fixed up like
the Sac & Fox Indians
I saw in that large
book of yours the
colored plates, He
says he thinks his
brother will sit for
me. I have had quite
a talk with Keokuk
through the interpreter

(3)
and what you
wrote me about him
is true. His wife is
half white and half
Sac during the Blackhawk
War her Mother swam
the Mississippi River
on horseback with the 
present Keokuks wife
on her back.
Keokuk likes to talk of
old times he is a fine
man very religious &
thoroughly trustworthy
and highly respected.
his house is as clean &
nice as any white mans.
Were these Sac & Fox
Indians the ones that

lived around Big Foot?
And did they name 
the place?
In my travels I have
seen or heard of an
Indian named Big foot.
The Pottawatomies are
around here also the
Iowa Indians & a distinct
tribe I may paint
some of them
I have moved my 
quarters and am now 
better fixed have a 
nice room to sleep in
The only trouble have a
feather mattress with

(5) about one fourth
enough feathers in it
The best beds I have
had to sleep in have
been in the hay in the barns with
blankets under me
& the nice new mown
hay made a fine bed.
I am having better luck 
here than anticipated
I stopped work on
Keokuks other picture
as was afraid
Blackhawks grand son
would go home.
You may not like
Keokuks picture on
account of his being
dressed in his Sunday
clothes but I had to

paint him that way or
not at all,
I may go to Darlington
& then to Anadarka
from here There are
several good Chiefs at
both places hav'nt
painted.
I am gaining a little
right along the game is
so plentiful here that
I can go half a mile
& get game enough to
keep myself supplied
with good eating
Saturday eve" three
of us are going

(7) hunting to be gone
until Sunday night
We may get some Deer
Did you get the
Nov number of Brush
& Pencil? I wrote an 
article about Indians
in Art and have reced"
a nice complimentary
letter on it from an
Indian man out
West.
Your affectionate
nephew.
Elbridge

Sac & Fox.
Agency.
Okla. T.
Nov. 27. 1900.
My dear Uncle
Guess I told you
I had changed my
quarters and am much
better fixed. I keep my
self in game as there
is such fine shooting 
here but am getting
tired of eating Quail.
I finished another
picture of Keokuk to
day and got a good
picture of him.
Am painting now

an Ottawa Indian
in full Ottawa costume
face painted etc.
And Today I engaged
an Iowa Indian to
sit for me a Chief
They are a distinct
type by them selves
different features altogether 
from any Indians
I have seen he is to
bring his costume.
I never heard of the 
Iowas until came
here There are 24 or 25
different tribes in
Oklahoma Territory.

(3) There are also some
Pottawatomies here.
You have often told me
I ought to have a
guardian in a joking
way but I would be
better off if I had had
a guardian since have
been painting Indians
I would have managed
those Indian reproductions
different. I want to
ask you Uncle Ed
if I have a right
to examine the books
pertaining to my account
on the Indian reproductions
so far I have taken
their word for the 
business done and I

hav'nt got out of it scarcely
$1000.00. It seems to me
I have a right to have
a man look over their
books as it is now
I have only their word
and statements sent
me which doesnt look
like good business to 
me. I should have made
a good thing out of those
reproductions as it 
stands now They have
the money and I the 
reputation. I wish you
would advise me.
How I wish I was a

(5)
good business man.
I could have been pretty
well fixed now. but
I never heard of an Artist
that was worth any
thing at business if
he was he was a poor
Artist.
But I am thankful I
control the original pictures
and I have something
like 125 now are
worth a good deal
My next exhibition will
be very interesting on
account of so many
different types.
I will try & visit all 
the different tribes here 
this time.
The profile finished of

Keokuk today is one of
my very best portraits
His wife is very interesting
I am gaining right along
am not near so nervous.
At one time thought I
had painted my last
Indian but as things
are now I hope to 
get portraits of all the
different tribes in
America.
I received a letter from
Maratta he expects to 
come here soon. He has
finished the Grand
Canon for the Santa Fe

(7) R.R. wish you could
see it am sure you would
pronounce it the best
thing you have seen of the 
Canon. Mr Higgins thought
so.
I would be better contented
if my wife was with me
she could see that I got
proper food to eat even
if she had to cook it her
self. I have been writing
my experiences among
the Indians and my wife
now is correcting it
and later on am to 
have it published in
book form well illustrated
and am going to have 
the book dedicated to you.

after my wife has got
it in better shape I will
have some good writer
look it all over and get
it in fine shape before
publishing it. and on
this book I am going to
be sharp am not going
to let some one else have
all the profit.
What do you think of the
idea of the book?
Your affectionate
nephew
Elbridge

12/1/00
Sac & Fox Agency
Okla. T. 
Dec 1 1900.
My dear Uncle
Yours unclear 
Just as soon as Blood hound's grand sons picture is dry enough will send it with Dooduds? to you by Express. It is one of the very best pictures I ever painted
I ordered a frame for unclear picture of Thusher? will order another one for Bloodhounds  so when you receive the pictures you can take them there and have framed.
I will get some more good subjects here from the outlook another Sac & Fox Chief is to sit for me and I guess I will get a Shawnie Chief to sit for me also. 
The unclear is as fine a man as I ever met thoroughly honest and a devoted member

of the church. 
Yes I have lots of sport hunting
I work five hours a day when I can get Indians to sit for me. The great trouble is the food these people dont seem to have serve enough to eat proper food when they have so much land to raise vegetables but I think it is pure lazyiness 
To day I will buy some eggs and have them cooked. They have plenty of onions but never cooked them until I asked them to.
I see Earnest S. Thompson is in Chicago lecturing unclear you could meet him.
There is a tribe of Indians in Kansas that I will visit on my way home They are becoming extinct as fast as possible, They belong to the same tribe in Northern California, They must have

been a very warlike people
Am glad to know what tribe it was that lived around Harvard The Pattamattomies? of Sac & Fox must have mingled with each other a good deal on older times as a Sac & Fox Indian told me in their langogues were very similar that they could converse with each other easily.
I am getting better right along slept good last night.
When I am alright again, will be better than ever in every May.
With love to Aunt Emma
Your devoted nephew
Elbridge

Sac & Fox Agency
Okla T.
12/5/00
Dec 5 1900.
My dear Uncle
Yours nerd? and glad to hear from you.
I have been waiting now four days for two Indians to come that have promised to sit for me. One is an Iowa Indian Chief and the other a Sac & Fox Chief.
Enclose send you a few notes my wife sent me I had her look up the Sac & Fox Indians history and you will see the Sox & Fox Indians joined unclear in about 1765 
Yes I ought to have my wife with me.
I have been thinking seriously about a tent and regular camping out fit I could have a tent arranged so could have a

Studio in it that is I could have opaque cloth inside so that the sun light would've change the light so that the light would be the same in the tent whether the sun was shining or not, a window could be made to fold up when traveling and could be fastened on the tent to work by, my wife and I could keep house & could have comfortable cots to sleep on and the great advantage the tent could be taken and put up any where and we would be independent could have healthy wholesome food well cooked to eat and then I could be right where my subjects lived The tent & whole thing could be shipped by freight ahead & hauled around by wagon.
At the Indian Agencys very few of the Indians live right near the

Agency they generally live from two to forty miles away.
At unclear there are several Chiefs that I never have been able to get because they never happened to be at the Fait? when I was as if they did come, di'd'n't have time to sit as had to return home Indians like to be followed up.
Chief Big Tree a Rionca? Chief of note lives 20 miles from Tit Sill he would sit for me but I would have to go out to his place I never mwent because there were no accomodations there except Indian fare.
What do you think of the tent idea? The whole thing could be got up for less than $75.00 and just one Indian picture would more than pay for it. I could travel my

old route all once again and get Indians couldn't get before and the living would be so much cheaper.
I have fun hunting there are two of the finest hunting dogs here I ever seen. but i have eaten so much quail that it makes me a little sick to see one.
An Indian made a speech here Thanksgiving to some Indian school children which was fine. Today I asked him if he would write that speech down I would have it published and I would send the speech to you. He is very enthusiastic over the work I am doing and is lots of help to me.
Your devoted nephew
Elbridge.

Sac & Fox Agency
Okla T.
Dec. 12 1900  12/12/00
My dear Uncle
Yours received &
glad to hear from you.
Tomorrow I will send
the two Keokuks pictures
and one of Blackhawks
grand son to Thurber to
be framed. I want them
to let you know when the
pictures arrived so that
you could choose the one
of Keokuk you wished
me is a front view & one
a profile Mr Butler has 
bought me of Keokuk he
will take the one you do
not he wants a picture

of Black hawks grandson
so will they and get
him to sit for another
I have been looking now
more than a week waiting
for the Indians to come in
that have promised me is 
to be here sure this week
there has been sickness &
one death among them
& a Chief who was to
come he was delayed by
his sons wife having a
pair of twins.
I have written an article
for the Past which will
be published some Saturday
soon, they have been waiting
for a Sac & Fox picture
I have instructed Mr
Dyer to have me of KeoKuks
pictures photographed
4218

(3)
you might have the one you
select photographed as
I will want it for this
book. I am going to have
the book nicely illustrated
Mc Clures Magazine wrote
me to send the ?s to them
and they would publish
it in the Magazine in
parts which would be a
good idea then afterwards
have it published in book
form. Hereafter I am going
to keep my eyes open and
when I see a chance to
make some money out of my
work take advantage of
it. Do you know Uncle Ed
12-12-00

that unclear I have been?
painting Indians which
is only a little over three years if
I had used better judgment
I would have money enough
now to last me the rest
of my life, but I think the
book will take, am going
to have Maratta make the
cover design, it will be a
big job to get the manuscript
in shape for print
but T at is at work on it
now, she wrote a fine
article for Harpers Weekly 
about White Swan I
painted they gave us
$55.00 for the article &
illustrations The article has
not come out yet but
I think it will soon.

(5)
I am getting better things
to eat now the woman is 
my kind she does all sh
can I have eggs every
morning now and vegetables
such as potatoes cabbage
turnips & onions so am
all right. I take long
walks every day. Today
have been working on my 
story. When I first commenced
to paint Indians the idea
did not come to me to
write my experience wich
I had thought of it then
and every new tribe I visited
hired an interpreter to be with
me all day and

all the Indians said about
my work which would be
more interesting. I remember
on Pretty Eagle sat back of
me when I was painting
and Talked and a white
man who understood Crow
was present and he told me
what Pretty Eagle said,
he said that man makes
unclear wipes and
there is an eye etc.
He said he never knew that
a white man could ever
make picture he said a great
many Indians can.
I thought that the

(7) Pattawattomies & Sac
& Foxes must have mingled
as their language is similar
there is one Pattawattomie
her and some Ottawas
who are very sweet and
intelligent people one of
them is a Minister here
preaches every Sunday.
I think you will prefer
the Profile of Keokuk
to the front view as it
is such as strong resemblance
to Henry Ward Beecher.
Your offectionate
nephew Elbridge.

Sac & Fox Agency
Okla. T.
Dec 28 1900   12/28/00
My dear Uncle
Mr Dyer wrote me
that you select the front
view of Keokuk and one of
Blackhawks grand son.
I have finished another of
Blackhawks grand son for
Mr Butler and the other
grand son has promised to
sit for me after New Years.
I am now painting a
portrait of the only living
Shawnee Chief he is an old
white headin Indian and 
a fine man in every way
his word is as good as gold

His white name is Long
Tom Washington he is
called Washington from
his resemblance to Washington
his Indian name is
Chief Lo-waine-wag-she-kah
he probably will sit for
two portraits. I am
gradually getting more
like my self I get pretty
good things to eat now
such as vegetables & eggs
& wild game which is 
plentiful here.
I have been expecting to go
to the Quaw paw Agency
but there are some more
Indians I want to get
here.
I will get the Modocs
at Quaw paw and other
tribes.
4218

The old Chief im painting
now has quite a history
he has killed 7 white men
they were horse thiefs
His brother was a muted
Chief Big Jim he died
four months ago.
As soon as the picture
is dry enough will send
it and two Kickapous
and one Ottawa will
exhibit the old Chiefs
picture in Art Institute.
I see Maratta has got out
a nice booklet for Santa
Fe R.R.
Wishing you all a 
Happy New Year
Your devoted nephew
Elbridge.

Sac & Fox Agency 1/2/01
Okla. T.
Jan. 2 - 1901
My dear Uncle
Yours of Dec 31
just received.
The Ottawa I painted
in a good type but he
is not a Chief
I saw him often receiving
your letter and asked
him about the Ottawas
He says a good many
Ottawas are at Quaw paw
Agency some 100 miles
from here in Oklahoma
T. that one Ottawa Chief
is there, there there are
some Ottawas in Canada

some in Colorado and
a good many in
Michigan and some
scattered in other states
They all are pretty well
civilized There are two
here both speak English
fluently.
Newly are the Ottawa
have a mustache and 
Told they wore a mustache
in older times.
When I go to Quaw paw
will try and get the
Ottawa Chief to sit
for me. I am expecting
the other Blackhawk
grand son in every day
his Indian name translated
is Blackhawk.
4218

(3) I am quite sure I
can get the Ottawa
Chief to sit for me.
Quaw paw is the home
for the Ottawas in Okla
T.
I finished a good
picture of the only Shawnee
Chief he is a very old
man and won't live long
his hair is whit, had
quite a time to get
hime to sit.
I would like to be
remembered to Dr Favill
With best wishes for
the New Year
Your devoted nephew
Elbridge.

Sac & Fox Agency 1/3/01
Okla. T.
Jan3 1901
My dear Uncle,
Since writing you
yesterday I find that
there is an Ottawa
Chief here he is an
inherited Chief and a
very smart bright man
his Father was a Chief
so was his Grand Father
and his Great Grand Father
was the noted Chief Pontiac
that Pontiac Mich was
named after. He is to
sit for me tomorrow
in costume and if
Dr Favill wants the

picture he may have it
He told me his Indians
name but I have forgotten
it, translated means
"Noon day"
He speaks English as
well as any white man
and is a member of the
Baptist Church
Keokuk called to see me
today and I think the
old fellow wants to
sit for another picture.
His picture the one you have
has been photographed
and you can get one of
Thurbers if you wish it.
Your devoted nephew
Elbridge
4218

P.S. This Ottawa Chiefs
white name is William Her.
and in case Dr Favill
wished to he could correspond
with him and get his whole
history where he was born
etc and all about
his Great Grand Father
Pontiac, He told me it 
was a wish of Pontiac
to always preserve his
name by namming some
of his children Pontiac
and so far that wish has
been adhered to, There is a 
relative here now named
Pontiac after him he is called
Ponty.

                          1-3-01

Sac & Fox Agency
Okla. T.
Jan 5 1901
My dear Uncle
Since writing you
I have found out that
the old Chief I painted
whose white name
is Long Tom Washington
is a great grand son
of Tecumseh. This picture
I will send to the
Art Institute This place
seems to have so many
nation descendents.
Am getting a first
picture of Pontiac's decendent
will paint two
portraits of him he
is fixed up in Ottawa costume

Tecumsehs descendent is
to sit for another pictures
Keokuk was in to see
me again Today and he
wants to sit for another
portrait all dress up
in Sac & Fox costume
he has sent any for
the costume so I am
liable to remain her for
some time I have changed
my room am now sleeping
in same room I work in
which is better as have
a stove in my room &
can take a bath. I caught
an awful cold in the
other room and came near
having pneumonia which
is very prevalient here
4218

(3) My wife is busy
working on my book.
I received a letter from
Mr Maratta and he thinks
I ought to get some good
Author in Western Stories
to rewrite and finish the
story for me he suggests
Mr. E. Hough who wrote
the girl at the half way
house. The story of the 
cowboy etc etc
Mr Maratta thinks that
my wife would loose
the Western flavor which
is true as she never has
been West
Mr Maratta is to design
the book and cover for
me.
I will look out and see
that I don't get robbed

                       1-5-01

in this book and get all
there is due me and I
think it will bring me
in a fair income. of course
I will give you one book
as it is to be dedicated
to you and I am going
to have it worded nice
and let you see it before
it is printed in the book.
Pontiacs descendent says
he will be pleased to 
correspond with Dr Favill
and tell him all about
him self he knows a
good deal of Pontiacs
History which has been
handed down in the
family.
With love to you & Aunt Emma
Your devoted nephew
Elbridge

Sac & Fox Agency
Okla. T.
Jan 13 1901           1/13/01
My dear Uncle
Your received
If Keokuk sits for
another portrait in costume
you can exchange the one
you now have for it.
I have changed my
mind in regard to the
book will have my wife
write it all as she is
fully capable of doing it
then we wont have to pay
some one else for rewriting
it.
the Sac & Fox Indians
held a counsil in my
room for two day so

I couldn't work.
Keokuk was the head
speaker he gets very
eloquent. the talk was
translated to the Agent
and it surprised me to
see how these Indians
weighed each subject
and how very careful
they were that the different
problems They had to deal
with were handled so
carefully and what a
lot they had to say
on each subject
One of the things they had
to settle was a white woman
with two children who was
related to the Sac & Fox
and she wanted to draw
annuity money
4218

(3) but the Indians Told
her she must give absolute
proof that these were her
children so she has to write
back and get the Doctors
proof also proofs in the
Church where they were
Christened etc There an
old lady where Mother
was a Sac & Fox member
to you. the tribe. She knew
Keokuks Father but she
has got to give proof
that will be hard for her
to get to establish her
relation to the Sac & Fox
One Indians got up and
said we all had Mothers
once and they raised us
and were good to us but
none of us here have any
Mothers living and he

                        1-13-01

says one must not be
harsh with this old lady
etc. Tomorrow I will
finish Pontiacs grand son
Am getting a good picture
of him in costume.
Haven't heard fro Dr
Favill as yet.
With best wishes
Your devoted nephew
Elbridge.

Sac & Fox Agency    1/26/01
Okla. T.
Jan 26 1901.
My dear Uncle
I have the picture
finished of the Ottawa
Chief for Dr Favill to
see I sent some more
pictures to Thurber would
like to have you see them
I have been looking
for a good deal waiting
for Indians but I
don't mind it as I
haven't been well
Mr Kimbark who 
has charge of the
Indian plates wants
to sell the 54 plates

for $?.000 he thinks it
would be a good plan
if some one would buy
the plates and put them
away for some ten
years then bring them
out again.
As things have turned
out with the plates
it would have been better
I think if I never had
allowed them to be
reproduced in colors
but still it has been an
education to the public
and has mad me
known pretty well over
the country, whether it
has hurt the side of
Indians pictures is
a question
4218

(3) The last 21 Indian
plates that were made
was made on this
condition, that if the
Paper Milles Co (Kimbark)
did not buy a certain
number of pictures in a
enough to pay for
the 21 plates the color
type people would use
the plates but in either
case I get my commission
just the same, but the
trouble is the color type
people will use there for
advertising purposes
and if the 54 plates
could all be bought
then they could not use
them.
If I could afford it
I would buy them my

                 1-26-01

self and think in ten
years they could be
brought out again with
screens.
I called on Mrs Keokuk
last week? she is a bright
smart woman and knows
a lot of Indian history
that is pertaining to the
Sac & Fox Indians
When do you start for
Europe?
Your devoted nephew
Elbridge.

HOTEL DE MONT - image
Finest Hotel                      Fine Sample Room
In the Country.                  Accommodations...

         HOTEL
         DE MONT
           MONT HALL, Proprietor.

Seneca, Mo., Feb 2 1901
My dear Uncle
Yours received
It is hard to get the Indians
to take off their lather, the bead
belt around Washington is typical
Shawnee and in older times was
always worn by them. He is a
good sample on account of being
a grand son of Tecumseh and the
only Shawnee Chief living.
The Indian plates will not be
destroyed but probably the color
type people will use them for
advertising purposes.
I have no peony in the plates
at all
Thanks for mentioning my
Indian pictures to Mr. Hacket.
I arrived here last night
and had intended going out to
Ayer MS 120

the Quaw Paw Agency 4 miles
from here  but I can get the Indians
to come here as well as 
the Hotel is comfortable good
Tables and reasonable in price
have concluded to remain here
I have a Modoc engaged to
come Monday.
The two noted Modocs Chiefs are
dead one died 15 years ago
The other 10 years ago They were
Scar faced Charlie & Steamboat
Frank. The Modocs remind me
of the Apaches They are rather
small in stature but were built
there are several tribes of Indians
living around here.
Your devoted nephew
Elbridge.
4218

Seneca. Mo. 2/6/01
Feb. 6. 1901
My dear Uncle
I am painting
a Modoc Chief he was
in the famous Modoc
war in the lava beds
where afterwards Capt
Jack was hung.
There are only 13 Modoc
men here They remind me
very much of the Apaches
and the fellow I am
painting resembles Geronimo
a little that is his chin
these Modoc are very
industrious they chop around
and haul it to town
Ayer MS 120

to sell the Chief is
sitting for me in costume
and face painted, they
all when dressed in
costume wear a sort of
hat beaded and feathers
stuck in it.
The seem to be a very
honorable race of men.
Mr Kimbark thinks they
will let the Indian plates
rest now for a few years
and bring them out again.
They control 33 plates while
the Calo? type people control
21 but I get royalty on
all of them.
The Hotel I am stopping at
is a good place good
thing to eat
Your devoted nephew
Elbridge.
4218

Seneca Mo.
Quaw paw Agency
Mch. 9 1901
My dear Uncle
My wife surprised
me yesterday by coming
here and I am awfully
glad she is here as she
is company for me &
she will get some good
Indian stories here.
I have finished one picture
of Chief Yellow Hammer.
and am painting another
of him in first Modoc
costume he was in the
Modoc war.
A Seneca Chief is to sit
for me in costume.
Ayer MS 120

I sold the other two pictures
of Keokuk & Blackhawk
and think one of Yellow
Hammer is sold.
I have found out the true
? of wampum and
nearly every unclear when think
they know about wampum
are mistaken and was
what it really was used for.
It was in the shape of a
belt but never worn
and was used as a
sort of agreement between
two tribes each tribe in
older times had a wampum
reader and only he could
read the belt. far westward? 
one time a tribe of Indians
wanted to be a peace with
the Siouxs so they sent
their wampum belt to the
Siouxs and it read unclear
4218

(3)
want to be at peace with you
The Siouxs made a wampum
belt and sent to
the other tribe it had on
it a picture of a Sioux with
his hand extended to shake
hands but in his other
hand held a bow and arrow
back of him which ment
we are willing to be friends
but we are always prepared
for war.
A man here who has
a good deal of Wyandotte
blood in his veins tells
me this he has a wampum
belt now more than one
hundred years old which
Ayer MS 120    3-9-01

had quite a history.
I am taking it easy
am not working hard
at all and am in
papas? to be my self
before living I am
much better
With love to you and 
Aunt Emma
Your offectionate nephew
Elbridge.

Darlington O.T.
Mch. 25. 1901.
My dear Uncle
(Excuse paper all I have)
We arrived here yesterday
and I am going to paint
all the Chiefs There I did
not get where here before
Black coyote is to sit
again. you have one of him.
I cant tell you how
much better I feel to have
my wife with me. she
is so much company
for me keeps my room
in nice order and sees
that I get proper food
to eat and if necessary
cooks her self I used
Ayer MS 120

to get so awfully unclear
when alone The life itself
was bad enough and
it was a mistake I didn't
take her with me from the
very beginning what extra
expense there is I can
make up by doing better
work, there she is a good
writer when we were in Germany
she wrote articles for
newspapers here and some
of the other papers gave her
complimentary notions on
her writing, wish I had
shown you the articles she 
wrote that I have in my
scrap book. There she has
such fine chances to get
Indians stories from the
Indians Yellow Hammer
4218

(3) The Modoc told her
all about the Modoc ?
then a Wyandott Indian told
here a lot of five Indian
legends she is busy all
the time writing then years
ago she wrote an article
about White Swan for
Harpers Weekly which they
gave us $55.00 for the
article will come out soon
and will send you one.
Am sure she can pay
her way with me by
writing about the Indians
and am sure the Santa Fe
will give her unclear as
her stories will be published,
next Winter we meant to
go along the Santa Fe
road I want to get
samples of the Toaz
Ayer MS 120 3-25-01

Pueblos the Isleta Pueblos
& the Acoma Pueblos
as well as the Pima &
Maricopa and those?
Indians living in the
Grand Canon.
We are working on our book
all the time, here is how
it starts off hope it
will pleas you if not let
me know.
An Artists is forever
among the Indians
by E. A. Burbank
I left Chicago March
9th 1897 for Ft Sill O.T.
commissioned to paint
a portrait for Mr
Edmund E. Ayer of Chicago
of Chief Geronimo.
Mr Ayer has been the
Indians friend all his
life and has called?

(5) and presented to the
Field Columbian Museum
(of which he was its first
President) the largest
collection ever got together
of American Indian c?s
He also has the most
extensive library in existence
of Indian literature which
he has presented to the
Newberry library of
Chicago. The rest goes
on with my experiences.
I think it would have
been a good investment if
I had hired a good man
to act as guardian
over me just had him
watch me and manage
things am sure I could
have made $50.000 on
those Indians reproductions
Ayer MS 120 3-25-01

it make me feel bad
as I have worked so
hard all my life and
those chances dont
happen often. but am
sure I will do well on
the book I will have
some 60 five page
illustrations in it in half
tone with the owners under
each picture. I have a
lot of good interesting
stories to tell about
the Indians, and I shall
keep my eyes open and
see that some one else
dont get all the money
as was the case with
the color reproductions
it seems as though I
had a right to examine

(7)their books as according
to the commission I have
received they have done
only $12.000 worth of
business.
Now that my wife
is with me I am not
working so hard and
looking out for my health,
before I over worked and
kept on over working
forced my self to work
and then on top of it all
eating such poor
unhealthy food not
nourishing at all I
believe if kept in my
mind would have
become effected
My wife gets along
fine with the Indians
Ayer MS 120 3-25-01

she seems to like the life
think I have sold one of
Yellow Hammers portraits
I have a good customer
in Mr Butler he has bought
some 15 of my Indians
all Chiefs. The picture
I had at the Paris Exposition
is back a Navajo
you haven't any if you
want it let me know
Mr Butler may want
it she is dressed in
Navajo costume all
through. Shall be glad
to hear from you With love
to you & Aunt Emma
Your devoted nephew
Elbridge.

JAN 3-1903 -- Stamp
Rosbud. S. Dak.
Dec 26 - 1902
My dear Uncle
I send you
tomorrow by express
40 red chalk drawings
12 of these are drawings
like the ones you first
bought of me the rest
are a more finished
portrait, but you can
have them at the
same price $10.00 each
Thurber sells them
for $15.00 & $20.00 each
Im having a hard

time to get the Indians
to pose as the weather
is so cold they no
not come in as often
as they did but I
will remain here until
half all the important
Chiefs.
Wishing you all a
Happy New Year
Your offectionate
nephew
Elbridge.
4218

Rosebud. S. Dak.
Jan 28 1903
My dear Uncle
Yours of Jan 21 received.
I have only finished
four oil portraits but
I have several more
started. I would have
had several finished
but the Indians disappointed
me in coming
but they are coming now
all right I have 
several red drawings and
as soon as I get some
more will send them

to the office as
you suggest.
I will send all the
paintings to the office
also.
I hardly care to have
another exhibition
at Thurber as it is 
rather exhausive and I 
am sure I can dispense
of them to private individuals
even if I only need
a few the pictures will
be all the more
valuable in later
years.
The weather has turned
cold again.
I would send what
oil portraits I now
have but they are not
4218

dry enough to
varnish out.
wishing you and
Aunt Emma a
happy voyage
Your offectionate nephew
Elbridge.

pageContext.title: E.A. Burbank letters, 1900-1902
